awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Novel Reusable Launch Platform: Two-Body Separation Under Unique Aerodynamic Circumstances
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact and commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is in its positive influence on both the growth of the Low Earth Orbit economy and stimulation of innovation in space technology. The growing demand for satellite launches is currently limited by a bottleneck of low availability, flexibility, and high cost of existing orbital launch services. Orbital delivery services enabled by this advanced in-flight separation system will enable a new level of launch responsiveness leading to lower costs, much greater contractual flexibility, and the availability of daily launches without the need for costly launch infrastructure, greatly accelerating time-to-market for satellite service providers and increasing their profitability. Low cost and frequent access to Low Earth Orbit will enable ubiquitous internet access, 5G capabilities, and valuable Earth observation technologies. The flexibility and reduced cost of these launch services will help maintain the United States' position at the forefront of space technology development and space research. The technology will provide the US Armed Forces access to a responsive, secure, flexible, and available gateway to space that will boost reconnaissance, observation, communication, and intelligence capabilities. Moreover, it will represent the most ecofriendly launch delivery service available, able to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by three times (3x) compared to ground launch.

This SBIR Phase I project seeks to demonstrate an innovative concept of in-flight aircraft/rocket separation in which the rocket is launched from the top of the carrier aircraft, instead of the widely used launch from beneath. This new separation system is the core innovation enabling an advanced air-launched orbital delivery system that will dramatically reduce the cost of dedicated satellite launch, minimize propulsion and structural requirements, and enable orbital delivery flexibility and precision, while significantly reducing the carbon footprint of space launch operations. The proposed concept will be the first top-carry air-launch service commercially available. The goals of the Phase I project are focused on building a prototype of the separation system and validating it in a sub-orbital test flight. The main technical challenge is to ensure that the design of the improved separation system will work under a broad range of real flight conditions. This technology will be achieved by research leading to a better understanding of aerodynamic behavior at the separation event and the development of an improved design methodology that considers all relevant design parameters and their aerodynamic effects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Fenix Space, Inc. has validated top-carry and top-launch design and analysis techniques using a combination of six-degree-of-freedom (6-DOF) analysis refined with computational fluid dynamics (CFD) modeling. Using the results of 1/5-scale flight test results as a starting point, Fenix developed the analysis and modeling techniques to ensure a clean two-body separation of a rocket body from the top of an aircraft under varying conditions of altitude, velocity, gamma angle and atmospheric wind.

Separating a launch vehicle from the top of an aircraft is a key technical risk to resolve for the development and realization of the disruptive innovation provided by the Fenix launch system architecture. Previously, Fenix successfully demonstrated top separation at 1/5 scale, low altitude, low speed, and in calm wind conditions. In this NSF project, Fenix has developed the analysis and modeling methodology to be able to achieve top separation under a very broad range of altitudes, gamma angles, velocities and atmospheric wind conditions, and to be able to analyze and design for launch vehicles with various aerodynamic shapes. There has been no commercially deployed system that launches a rocket from a top-carry position. Our successful 1/5 scale flight test and separation demonstration, albeit in very favorable conditions, was the validation of Fenix preliminary analyses. The work achieved by Fenix in this NSF project generated further understanding of how to achieve a clean two-body aerodynamic separation within a broader set of conditions.

The cumulative performance benefits that this innovation unlocks will disrupt launch services for orbital, hypersonic and missile defense testing, and terrestrial critical supply delivery:

  • 20x improvement in time from payload completion to on-orbit delivery

 

  • Inexpensive enough to deploy launch systems broadly, creating a highly resilient launch capability

 

  • Leverages existing infrastructure (airports) to enable 1000x increase in national launch cadence

 

  • 90% system reusability

 

  • 6x reduction in CO2 emissions per unit mass to orbit compared to ground launch

 

  • 75x improvement in payload to orbit versus current air launch systems using same aircraft.

In addition to the work accomplished on this NSF project, Fenix has developed significant intellectual property in the areas of tow launch trajectory analysis, GN&C, avionics, rocket-propelled composite aircraft design and fabrication, liquid oxygen/liquid methane ignition, combustion device design and fabrication, propulsion system design and fabrication, and ground support systems for responsive launch.

 


Last Modified: 01/14/2025
Modified by: Paul Phillipsen
